content.description: This is the leftmost bolted line.
content.location: This is the first route as you approach the crag from the bottom. The hangers are bright silver, and chains and rap rings are visible from the bottom.

content.description: This is a nice romp up large edges to a crux pull just before the anchor.
content.protection: 2 bolt anchor. It has not yet been equipped.
content.location:
This is the second route from the top of the crag and shares small sections of climbing with

Council

to its right.

content.description:
Starting from same SDS as

Prairie Dog

, traverse break a few feet before making a big lunge straight up to a good crimp. Finish directly. See the beta video for holds ‘in’ the problem.

I believe this is a new FA - the rock looked uncleaned, and there is still a bit of loose rock up top. Right as you hop the guard rail to head up Elk Creek, there is a steep boulder to the right. Start low on good holds with a good heel lock, pull up on crimps, and perform a crux mantel topout. This has really fun movement on okay rock right next to the road.
content.location:
It is right over the guard rail before you walk up the gully to

Prairie Dog

.

content.description:
Per

Monty

: This is the problem left of the arete on the right side of the boulder.  SDS on a undercling, work up right then back left on crimps to a positive top out.  Per

Joe Dunlap

: Partially sketchy landing on smaller boulders.
content.protection:
Per

Joe Dunlap

: A pad or two should do you good.
content.location:
Per

Joe Dunlap

: This boulder is just above the waterfall. Prairie Dog is on the upstream side of the boulder.

content.description: Order has beautiful stone and a crux in the last two bolts. There are larger features and diagonal cracks down low.
content.location: After a brushy breakdown in the cliff, this is the leftmost route of the uphill group of climbs. It ascends to its own tall-looking summit.

content.description: Problem starts on the furthest right side of the boulder on a right hand three finger crimp under the roof and a left hand slopey crimp then climb the arête right and up. Sit start is V10/11 and starts further down on the arête in a slopey dish.
This is a 17 foot, 40 degree overhang with long moves on good holds to a defined crux sequence near the top to a small crimp.  Start sitting.
content.location: This is the first boulder you see on your left when headed up Elk Creek.  The boulder (but not the climb) is visible from the road.

content.description:
Climb straight up through two slight overhangs to a shared anchor with

Evolvlution

to the left.
content.location: It is the rightmost of two brown hanger routes that converge to share an anchor at the top.

content.description: Problem starts all way in the back of the black roof and climbs on jugs till you reach one hard move to the lip (V11 move) and then finish up on Open Season V9+. 20 plus move, boulder problem.

The crux is gaining the left sidepull jug.  Start sitting on two jug-pinch underclings and do a few compression moves.  Try either a kneebar or a gastocling to get through the crux.  I'd recommend rapping off the top of the boulder and sorting the last V6 section before attempting from the ground as water comes down a black streak making some of the best holds through the upper section invisible.
content.location: Head uphill in the drainage from the Elk Creek Block 5 minutes.  Joy Division is on the left-facing wall and begins on two jug-pinch underclings.

content.description: This has a thin crux sequence with a couple longer reaches near the top.
content.location:
This route shares anchors with

Magic Rat Tail

to its right. It has brown hangers.

content.description: Climb the obvious crack from the ledge at the base of the overhang (there are 2 bolts to belay from). This will be a classic when it cleans up. It's a solid trad outing for those of you with the adventure itch. It's a bit dirty but totally worth climbing. Getting to the start is the crux - climb the first few bolts of  "Courage," 5.11+.
content.protection: Bring lots of big cams (Camalot #4 and #5s).
content.location: Walk south, up Elk Creek, negotiating the water polished rock riverbed. It's on your right and takes about 5 minutes to get to.

content.description: Jugs lead to a finger crack below two large, steep ledges.
content.location: This is the rightmost climb at the crag.

content.description:
Starts to the left of

Prarie Dog

, V5, and climbs the sloping rail left till the very end of the boulder and make a dicy top out. Sit start it on Prarie Dog V5 and it V9/10.
content.protection: 2 or more pads, depending how strong you are.

content.description: Problem starts on the furthest left side of the boulder on two bad slopey crimps at the edge of the roof, make a hard move to a slopey slot off of a right slopey heal toe cam, jugs to the lip after that.
